queries.description: Pointers stored in unrelated smart pointers can be erroneously destroyed upon a single underlying pointer going out of scope.
queries.name: An already-owned pointer value shall not be stored in an unrelated smart pointer

A20-8-1.title: An already-owned pointer value shall not be stored in an unrelated smart pointer.

queries.description: Sharing ownership of a raw pointer, including the underlying object of an std::unique_ptr, risks resource leakage and complicated scope.
queries.name: A std::unique_ptr shall be used to represent exclusive ownership

A20-8-2.title: A std::unique_ptr shall be used to represent exclusive ownership.

queries.description: An std::shared_ptr should be used to ensure that underlying objects remain valid if a different std::shared_ptr instance is destroyed.
queries.name: A std::shared_ptr shall be used to represent shared ownership

A20-8-3.title: A std::shared_ptr shall be used to represent shared ownership.

queries.description: An std::unique_ptr provides sufficient functionality and demonstrates intended usage without the overhead of std::shared_ptr if shared ownership is not required.
queries.name: A std::unique_ptr shall be used over std::shared_ptr if ownership sharing is not required

A20-8-4.title: A std::unique_ptr shall be used over std::shared_ptr if ownership sharing is not required.

queries.description: Using std::make_unique avoids explicit calls to 'new' and provides a safe way to allocate objects managed by std::unique_ptr.
queries.name: std::make_unique shall be used to construct objects owned by std::unique_ptr

A20-8-5.title: std::make_unique shall be used to construct objects owned by std::unique_ptr.

queries.description: Using std::make_shared avoids explicit calls to 'new' and provides a safe way to allocate objects managed by std::shared_ptr.
queries.name: std::make_shared shall be used to construct objects owned by std::shared_ptr

A20-8-6.title: std::make_shared shall be used to construct objects owned by std::shared_ptr.

queries.description: If a smart pointer object is passed into a function for uses which do not affect its lifetime, then a reference or raw pointer should be used instead.
queries.name: A smart pointer shall only be used as a parameter type if it expresses lifetime semantics

A8-4-11.title: A smart pointer shall only be used as a parameter type if it expresses lifetime semantics.

queries.description: A std::unique_ptr shall be passed to a function as: (1) a copy to express the function assumes ownership (2) an lvalue reference to express that the function replaces the managed object.
queries.name: A std::unique_ptr shall be passed to a function as a copy if the function assumes ownership, or as an lvalue reference if the function replaces the managed object

A8-4-12.title: A std::unique_ptr shall be passed to a function as: (1) a copy to express the function assumes ownership (2) an lvalue reference to express that the function replaces the managed object.

queries.description: A std::shared_ptr shall be passed to a function as: (1) a copy to express the function shares ownership (2) an lvalue reference to express that the function replaces the managed object (3) a const lvalue reference to express that the function retains a reference count.
queries.name: A std::shared_ptr shall be passed to a function as a copy if the function shares ownership, as an lvalue reference if the function replaces the managed object, or as a const lvalue reference if the function retains a reference count

A8-4-13.title: A std::shared_ptr shall be passed to a function as: (1) a copy to express the function shares ownership (2) an lvalue reference to express that the function replaces the managed object (3) a const lvalue reference to express that the function retains a reference count.
